Layouts and Positioning

Responsive Design

When designing responsively we need more than just fluid layouts (ie by using % widths rather than pixel widths). We often want to actually change the styles and layouts based on the size of the viewer’s screen or browser, and we can do that with media queries and responsive gridlex classes.

Responsive Grids 

One of the best things about Gridlex is how easy it is to create responsive grids. 

You just add ‘_size-colwidth’ to the end of the column size. So if you want it to be 6 columns wide on desktop, but collapse to full width on mobile you would write 

<div class="grid">
  <div class="col-6_sm-12"> ... </div>
  <div class="col-6_sm-12"> ... </div>
</div>

Gridlex has 4 sizes built in (large, medium, small and extra-small) each with set pixel widths that they are activated. You can change at multiple levels to. For example, let’s say you have a 4 column grid, that you want to drop to a 2 column grid on tablets and full width on mobile. This is what that would look like.. all without touching a line of css. 

<div class="grid">
  <div class="col-3_md-6_sm-12"> ... </div>
  <div class="col-3_md-6_sm-12"> ... </div>
  <div class="col-3_md-6_sm-12"> ... </div>
  <div class="col-3_md-6_sm-12"> ... </div>
</div>

Understanding Media Queries

Media queries introduce nesting to our CSS, just like we are already using for our HTML and any CSS written within the curly brackets of the media query is only applied if the browser width matches the criteria in the media query.

@media (max-width:720px) {
    ...
}

Any CSS selectors and properties written within this media query (where the … is) would only be applied if the screen width was 720px or smaller. As with html, when we are nesting CSS we indent in the CSS that’s inside the media query.

Any CSS can be written inside the media query, but common practices include changing the width of columns and adjusting the grid layout, simplifying the design, creating responsive menus, and showing and hiding elements.

SHOWING AND HIDING ELEMENTS

There is another display property value that we haven’t introduced yet which is display: none;. There is a pretty obvious reason for this, because if you were to apply display to all screen sizes then you may as well not create the element at all! Setting the display to none on certain screen sizes and then setting it back to block / inline or inline-block on other screen sizes allows you to customise what is displayed on your site for other devices and screen sizes.

Example - when the screen is smaller than 720px, anything with a class of mob-hide would dissapear, the header padding would shrink to 1% and the footer nav links would change their font-size and padding.

@media (max-width:720px) {
    .mob-hide { display: none; }
    header { padding: 1%; }
    footer nav a {
        font-size:1rem;
        padding: 0.5rem;
    }
}
